Even then, recordings alter your voice as well. So your voice on recording or in video still isn’t really how people hear you. The best way to listen to how you sound to other people is to take your hands and place them against your head, in front of your ears right by the temple. Put your hands in a vertical position and speak. That is what you sound like to other people. When you hold your hands like this, it greatly minimizes the bone vibrations in your skull. Allowing you to hear what your voice truly sounds like.

Here is it typed out if anyone needs to explain this to their friend or just wanted to sound smart or something:

basically, when u hear other peoples voices, you hear through air conduction, so the sound waves go through your ear, down the ear canal, amplified by small bones and then end up in the cochlea, where there are a bunch of hairs that send nerve signals to ur brain to interpret a sound. But When you hear your own voice, you hear it through bone conduction, so your vocal cords and bones vibrate (including skull). and because bones tend to transfer lower frequencies, people usually hear their own voice slightly lower than other people hear it. But when you hear your voice played back to you, there’s not any bone conduction, just air conduction, which makes it sound different to you since you are used to listening to your voice through bone conduction.

This is also why a lot of beginners in sound engineering EQ their own voice WAAAAAY to base heavy. They subcontiously try to replicate how they hear themselfs, but it just feels unnatural to others. (primarily because of room reverb, low freqencies usually get reflected less and transgress more)

So, as a common agreement in the industry, you never EQ yourself for a project if it is avoidable. For everyones sanity.

It’s not slightly lower, is it?  It’s just a stronger presence of the lower frequencies, right?  There’s many different frequencies going on when you make a sound, generally based off of the harmonic series.  The presence of the different frequencies makes up the tone.  Bone conduction would bring out the lower frequencies more, giving a deeper sound, but not lower.  Lower would be if you shift the harmonic series down, while deeper is just altering the presence of the different harmonics/fundamental.

Also comes down to speaker quality and mic quality

There is another reason too. If you know enough about audio recordings and equipment you'll know this, but most recordings are of low quality. It takes up too much storage to make something like a phone recording into a WAV file, instead of an MP3 and even MP3's have different qualities. What happens is that to save on space they delete small little parts of the file. It doesn't distort it so much that you can't understand it, but it distorts it enough that it sounds a bit off to us. Plus, it's added to the bone conduction thing he is describing. If you record your voice with very high quality equipment and have someone mix is down to get rid of background noise or whatever it won't sound as bad.

I am a singer with a falsetto voice. From deep baritone to lower soprano. Growing up in central Florida only added to my problems with a very Southern accent.
How I went from something I disliked to such a wide range:
First, I practiced cupping a hand behind one ear and sang the scales using various sounds like:
La. La la
Fi-ga-ro
A a a
Me me me
And when I was younger I tried, "Super cala fraja listic expi ala docious. From Mary Poppins.
Another technique is placing the back of one hand below the lower jaw and forcing it down with the muscle under the jaw.
Opening the jaw like going to a dentist appointment.
Grinning like the Joker on Batman which pulls the muscles on either side of the neck.
If your hands get tired, I've instructed people in my Church Choir to make partial clam shells, out of heavy craft paper, that can hook over each ear and will redirect the sound to the ears.
I'm almost 60 now. Haven't practiced as much lately and now my range has deepened to a deep baritone to alto.
If you practice, you can correct your voice.

Similar effect but not quite as severe when you play the violin. If you're setup correctly the violin touches your clavicle at the front. And if you don't use a shoulder rest there is even more contact. So you perceive bone conduction as well as air conduction when you play. Hearing a recording of your playing for the first time can be horrible 😭, but there are things you can do to improve the resonance.

Pretty good explanation but you left out one part. The actual way your brain perceives all this. Your brain pitch corrects your voice to sound somewhat normal. Bone conduction without your brain correcting it to sound normal would leave your voice sounding super deep.

When your brain recognizes a recording of your voice it pitch corrects it but there is no bone conduction to offset it. So your voice sounds slightly higher than it actually is. Your brain then realizes something is wrong and this causes a cringe feeling

Youll never be able to hear how you actually sound. You don't sound like you talk or like your recordings. Don't worry too much about hating your voice

With recording there is a slightly better explanation which is that because mics pick up sound and have to convert it to binary it has to sample from different points. Think of it like a grid the bit size being on the X axis and sample rate being on the side then put a sound wave in the middle the higher bit rate the more points a sample can be taken from and a higher sample speed means more samples in one second and no mic is currently advanced enough to sample our voices perfectly.

Gonna make a correction here. It’s not that you hear your own voice “lower” necessarily. Instead, you’re hearing the lower overtones of your own voice more prominently. It’s like how helium doesn’t make your voice “higher pitched”, it just emphasizes the high overtones and cuts out some of the lower ones. You’re therefore hearing a different timbre of sound, and pitch isn’t affected.

Does it make me weird that I don't hate my voice? I was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA until I was 23, but I've now lived in Seattle, WA for almost 35 years because I fell in love with it.

I had always been a singer and studio musician for pay, in clubs, for fairs and festivals, on my own recordings and for others, having been hired as a studio musician.

My mom took me to auditions in the city, and was my biggest (and best) advocate/manager since I was a child, and got me some very well-paying gigs. So I do know what my voice sounds like because I've made a number of recordings and had to do my own editing.

The one thing I do love about my voice is that it still has a Philly accent despite living out of town for over 37 years, (and sometimes I get a little homesick, so it's nice to hear my accent, even if it's from my own voice!)

I have friends in radio, and back when DJs were still being used live here in Seattle to play songs over the airwaves, they used to play me asking for some of my favorite songs to be played on their radio stations; for them to play certain requests back over the radio to my occasional embarrassment.

But I have heard my own voice, and I think that it would make a poor professional vocalist who doesn't like to hear themselves because listening to our own voices helps us keep our vocal "tricks" and exercises current and makes certain that one's voice doesn't fail and is still "up to snuff"

So I guess that keeps me from thinking that I'm weird because I don't hate my voice...
